Dialogue: Clean? Mr. Blackly sees cigarette smoke bleeding under his door.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Minny! Go get Momma!

Speaker: minny

Dialogue: I'm down! Minny jumps with a yelp, spins around.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Gone give me a heart attack! Missus Walters ambles toward the closet door. Minny quickly tries to turn her toward the front door. Missus Walters resists.

Speaker: missus walters
Dialogue: Minny, I'm getting my coat. Missus Walters opens the closet.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: It's ninety degrees out there, Missus Walters. Missus Walters pulls out a red, wool coat with cheetah print collar. The early stages of Alzheimer's have appeared, but Missus Walters is still quite proud at eighty percent capacity.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Minny, William took Billy out for ice cream. So, hurry back and get Billy down for his nap. No dilly dallying.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am. Minny raises the pie behind Hilly's beehive, dreaming of smashing it into her head.

Speaker: mae mobley
Dialogue: No!

Speaker: mae mobley
Dialogue: Nooo. Mae Mobley shakes her head.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: I give you a cookie if you go. Tee-tee immediately sprinkles into the bowl.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Aibileen, the girls are pulling up, and the table isn't set!

Speaker: mae mobley
Dialogue: Mae Mobley go, Momma!

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Get in your room! Right now! Mae Mobley rises behind Aibileen's leg.

Speaker: mae mobley
Dialogue: I sorry. Elizabeth reaches down and scoops up Mae Mobley like a sack of potatoes. Mae Mobley looks to Aibileen over her mother's shoulder, her eyes have welled up. Aibileen mouths "I love you" and blows her a kiss.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Hey, girls!

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Put Momma in a chair before she breaks a hip.

Speaker: missus walters
Dialogue: I'm not deaf yet, Hilly. Minny spies Aibileen in the corner and gives her a "here we go" look as she lowers Missus Walters into a chair. Hilly approaches Aibileen with the coat.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Aibileen, I want you to have this coat. It's too big for Momma now and it's way too expensive to put in the coat drive. Hilly extends the coat with a smile.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Thank you, Miss Hilly.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Go on. Try it on.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Hold on! Those are Miss Hilly's. Aibileen pulls another plate of eggs out of the fridge.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Forgive me, Lord, but I'm gonna have to kill that woman.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Watch yo mouth, Minny.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Looks like a walking Christmas present with all them bows. Aibileen shakes with silent laughter.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Oh, law! Did she?

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Uh-hum. But, I carry paper in from my own damn house. That fool don't know.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Hey, girls.

Speaker: jolene
Dialogue: Well, if it isn't Long-Haul- Skeeter. We didn't think you'd ever leave Ole Miss.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Well, it's supposed to take four years, Jolene. Skeeter spins around to Hilly and Elizabeth with a sigh.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: About supper club tonight...Honey, Stuart had to cancel.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Again? Hilly places her hand on Skeeter's shoulder.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: He can't get off the rig, Skeeter. It's offshore! Stuart is a very successful oil man.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I'm starting to think this Stuart is a figment of your imagination.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Raleigh called his cousin down in Hattiesburg. He'll drive up.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: The cousin with one eye?! Elizabeth nods.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: One eye?!

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I got a job today... at The Jackson Journal! Everyone looks at Skeeter as if she just threw up on herself. Finally, Hilly pats Skeeter on the leg.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: They'd be a fool not to hire you. Jolene raises her glass.

Speaker: jolene
Dialogue: To Skeeter...and her job. Last stop `til marriage. Hilly kicks Jolene under the table.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: The Miss Myrna column. Have y'all read it?

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Well, no! But, I bet the poor girls without any help, in South Jackson, read it like the King James. Everyone laughs. Skeeter's forehead crinkles.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Elizabeth, would you mind if I talk to Aibileen? To help me answer some of the letters? Just until I get a knack for it. Aibileen clears dishes as if she hasn't heard a thing. Elizabeth gets very still.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Aibileen? My Aibileen? What can't you just get Constantine to help you? Skeeter looks to her lap and shakes her head.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Constantine...quit us.

Speaker: elizabeth hilly
Dialogue: What?! Oh, my gosh! Skeeter nods her head sadly.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: I'm so sorry, Skeeter.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I really don't want to talk about it. Okay? The girls nod.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Well...I mean as long as it doesn't interfere with her work. A phone rings. Elizabeth nods to Aibileen.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Leefolt residence.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: She having bridge club right now. May I take a message? CELIA FOOTE, 28, peroxide blonde, stands in all her country girl glory. She speaks with a thick, unrefined, Southern accent, mired in insecurity.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: Please tell her Celia Foote called again. I'll call back tomorrow.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am. Celia nervously twists herself around in the phone cord.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: Ah-hem. Miss? "Miss" strikes Aibileen as very odd.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: No, ma'am.

Speaker: celia foote
Dialogue: Okay. Celia Foote. Emerson 6-8-4. Bye, now. Celia hands up the phone with a frown and sips from a coca- cola bottle.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Who was that on the phone?

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Miss Celia Foote called again. Elizabeth leans over and touches Hilly's arm.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: I've never called her back, Hilly.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: She can't take a hint, can she?

Speaker: jolene
Dialogue: Who's Celia Foote?

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: That tacky girl Johnny married.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Girl? I heard she's twenty-eight.

Speaker: jolene
Dialogue: Oh my God!

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Uh-hmm, worked concessions at a LSU game and sold him a hotdog. And, boy, he got a whole lot more. All the girls laugh.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Could have been you, Hilly.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: And live thirty minutes outside of town? Anyway, I ran into her at the beauty parlor, and she had the nerve to ask if she could help with the children's benefit.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Aren't we taking non-members? The benefit's gotten so big.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Yes, but we're not telling her. Everyone laughs but Skeeter. Aibileen pours Skeeter a cup of coffee. Skeeter looks up decidedly and smiles.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Thank you, Aibileen. Hilly begins squirming in her seat, obviously making a point. Elizabeth leans over.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Oh, Hilly, I wish you'd just go use the bathroom.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Ah-hem. I'm fine. Missus Walters shouts out from the sofa.

Speaker: missus walters
Dialogue: She's upset cause the nigra uses the guest bath, and so do we. Elizabeth turns to Aibileen.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Aibileen, go check on Mae Mobley. Aibileen disappears. Elizabeth leans into Hilly.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: If Aibileen uses the guest bathroom, I'm sure she uses yours too.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Wouldn't you rather them take their business outside? Skeeter sees a reflection of Aibileen listening off of a picture in the hall. Skeeter tries to change the subject.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Did y'all see the cover of "Life" this week? Jackie's never looked

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: -Tell Raleigh every penny he spends on a colored's bathroom, he'll get back in spades when y'all sell. It's just plain dangerous. Everybody knows they carry different diseases than we do. I double. Elizabeth takes a puff of her cigarette and fidgets with her cards.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: I can't ask Raleigh until tax season. But, it would be nice.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: That's why I've drafted The Home Help Sanitation Initiative.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: "The Home"...the what?!

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: As a disease preventative bill that requires every white home to have a separate bathroom for the colored help. I've even notified the Surgeon General of Mississippi. I'll pass. Skeeter again glances at Aibileen. Their eyes meet.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Maybe we ought to just build you a bathroom outside, Hilly. The room grows eerily quiet.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: You ought not to joke about the colored situation. Hilly leans in toward Skeeter.

Speaker: jolene
Dialogue: I have to skedaddle! Gotta get over to the station!

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Roses look like weeds next to you. Celia turns with a yelp. She slaps him playfully.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: Johnny, you scared the daylights out of me! Johnny begins kissing her neck.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Oh, who cares, honey. We got all we need right here. Johnny kisses her again and lowers her to the grass.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: Johnny, honestly!

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Doctor's orders. Johnny starts kissing Celia's breasts. She becomes uneasy and rolls out from under him.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: I don't know what's taking us so long. I'm sorry. Johnny brushes hair from Celia's face.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Hey, we've never done it in the yard. Maybe that's the trick. Celia seductively bites her lower lip.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: Watch my hair. Johnny's hand slides up her thigh.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Aibileen? Aibileen becomes nervous at the sight of Skeeter alone.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I had hoped to ask you myself if you could help me with the "Miss Myrna" letters...

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: So...Would you help me? Aibileen nods and looks out to Elizabeth on the street.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Miss Myrna gets it wrong lotta times. Be good to get it right.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Thank you, Aibileen. I plan on splitting the pay with you, too. Aibileen doesn't respond. She grabs a basket of rolls.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am, it is.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: That reminds me so much of my maid growing up. Aibileen starts wiping down a serving tray.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Constantine and me...were in church circle together.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: She loved me like you love Mae Mobley.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am. Skeeter moves closer to Aibileen.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Aibileen? How could she just quit like that? Aibileen stops wiping and looks up to Skeeter...

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Quit?

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Yes. When I got home from school last week, Momma said she had quit. Back in March to go live with her people up in Chicago. She didn't leave me a note or anything. Aibileen turns and resumes wiping the tray.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: No, ma'am. I couldn't...

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Do you have an address for her or anything? Aibileen shrugs her shoulders, reeling it all back in. Just then, Elizabeth walks into the kitchen holding papers stapled together. She looks between Aibileen and Skeeter.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: I'm sorry. Did I interrupt something? Skeeter and Aibileen shake their heads. Elizabeth hands Skeeter the papers. Home Help Sanitation Initiative is written on the cover.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Aibileen, I'll drop by at ten tomorrow to get started on Miss Myrna. Elizabeth looks at Aibileen.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Tomorrow is silver polishing day, so y'all make it quick, okay?

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Hey, Jameso.

Speaker: jameso
Dialogue: Hello, Miss Eugenia.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Momma! If the Smithsonian had wished to assemble the perfect antebellum home, Skeeter would be standing in it.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Momma? Skeeter's mother, CHARLOTTE BOUDREAU CANTELLE PHELAN, 50, glides into the room wearing a wig. Her floral print dress has a gazillion perfectly pressed pleats. Charlotte turns to a mirror and adjusts an auburn-colored, `pixie' cut.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Is this a little too young?

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: It's a little too everything.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Your daddy bought me this dress in

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Mom, I want to ask you about

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: -Right after Ole Miss won the Sugar Bowl. Charlotte unzips the dress and takes it off.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: What really happened? Charlotte winces with pain and grasps her stomach.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: I told you...she went to live with her people in Chicago...Now, Skeeter, your mother is dying, and she wants to see you in this dress. Charlotte stands in her slip and bra holding the dress. Skeeter begins taking off her clothes.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: How could she just take off without telling me?

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: I told her not to write you. I didn't want you upset in the middle of final exams. Honey, we were just a job to her. With them it's all about money...Did I tell you Fanny Peatrow got engaged? After she got that teller job, her mother said she was just swimming in proposals.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Good for "Fat Fanny Peatrow." She lowers the dress over Skeeter's head and zips it.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: This looks precious on you! Four years ago my daughter went off to college, and what did she come home with?

Speaker: skeeter charlotte
Dialogue: A diploma. A pretty piece of paper.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: They dropped out of college to become housewives, Mother.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: If only you'd show a little gumption, Eugenia...

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Well, I did get a job today.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: You did?

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Writing...for The Jackson Journal. Charlotte plumps up the dress around Skeeter's behind.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Great. You can write my obituary. "Charlotte Phelan dead. Her daughter still single."

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Momma, would it really be so terrible if I never met a husband? With that, Charlotte grabs Skeeter's hand and takes her to a love seat. They sit. This is serious.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: I need to...ask you something, Skeeter. I read the other day about how some girls...get unbalanced, start thinking these...well, unnatural thoughts. Charlotte begins to twist the handkerchief she holds.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Oh my God!

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Because, this article says there's a cure, a special root tea. Skeeter jumps up.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Mother, I want to be with girls as much as you wanna be with Jameso.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Eugenia! Skeeter storms out of the room.

Speaker: carlton
Dialogue: What the hell do you know about cleaning a house, Skeeter?

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: It's a start, Carlton.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: Leave your sister alone, Son. I'm proud of you, Sweetheart. Charlotte scoops up some broth with a spoon.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Oh, the irony of it all. Givin' advice on how to keep up a home when she... Charlotte's spoon goes in her mouth. Pascagolua tries to scoop some sort of casserole covered in almonds onto Skeeter's plate. Skeeter stops her.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Oh! No, Pascagolua! You couldn't have known this...But, see, I'm allergic to almonds.

Speaker: pascagolua
Dialogue: Sorry, Miss Eugenia.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Last time I had an almond, I stopped liking men. Charlotte glares at Skeeter. Carlton lets out a chuckle. Rebecca is mortified.

Speaker: rebecca
Dialogue: Oh my Lord.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: It's okay, Rebecca. They have a special root tea now.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: You have pushed it, Young Lady! Pascagolua scurries off. Skeeter turns to her father...

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Daddy, what happened to Constantine? The room grows silent. Carlton looks down to his plate.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: Ah...well, Constantine went to live with her family. People move on, Skeeter. But I do wish she'd stayed down here with us.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I don't believe you. Skeeter looks to her mother who immediately busies herself with scooping up more broth.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: You wouldn't understand. Not until you've hired help of your own.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: She raised me! Charlotte slaps the table and stands.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: She worked here for twenty-nine years. Charlotte presses both hands to her stomach.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: It was a colored thing, and I've put it behind me. Charlotte passes behind Rebecca and kisses her head.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Good luck down there, Carlton.

Speaker: carlton
Dialogue: Have fun at the dance, Skeeter Legs. Robert and Carlton race outside as Charlotte enters, healthy and glowing.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Eugenia! You've grown another inch since breakfast. Go put on a dress that fits before that boy and his daddy come pick you up. A horn blows. Charlotte kisses Skeeter on the cheek and then

Speaker: constantine
Dialogue: Gone be just you and me all weekend.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I just couldn't tell her I didn't get asked to the dance.

Speaker: constantine
Dialogue: Some things we should just keep to ourselves. Skeeter looks down to her long, bony legs.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I'm already taller than the boys' basketball coach. How tall are you, Constantine?

Speaker: constantine
Dialogue: I'm five-thirteen, so quit feeling sorry for yourself.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Momma was third runner up in the Miss South Carolina pageant.

Speaker: constantine
Dialogue: "Miss" what? Shoot, Child! You gone be "Miss Something Better." Constantine grabs Skeeter's hand and presses her thumb firmly to her palm.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: What about you? What did you want to be, Constantine? Constantine laughs.

Speaker: constantine
Dialogue: Oh, Child! We don't get to pick. This pick us, and that just how it is. Tight on Skeeter's face as Constantine gives her a big hug.

Speaker: jolene
Dialogue: Sunny skies and a high of ninety- eight today with ninety-nine percent humidity. There's a slight chance of afternoon showers so y'all carry an umbrella. Jolene pivots to camera, lowers her chin and smiles. Skeeter runs past Pascagoula with a phone and disappears inside the pantry.

Speaker: miss stein
Dialogue: What gave you this idea, Miss Phelan? I'm...curious.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I was...well, I was raised by a colored woman. I've seen how simple it can be and...well, how complex it can be, too...between the families and the help.

Speaker: miss stein
Dialogue: Continue.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I'd like to write something from the point of view of the help. These colored women raise white children, and then twenty years later those children become the employer. It's that irony, Miss Stein, that we love them and they love us yet...we don't even let them use the toilet in the house. Miss Stein's swivels her chair back around and sits up.

Speaker: miss stein
Dialogue: I'm listening.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Margaret Mitchell glorified the mammy figure who dedicates her whole life to a white family but no one...ever asked Mammy how she felt about it. There is both undisguised hate for white women and an inexplicable love, but nobody ever talks about it down here.

Speaker: miss stein
Dialogue: So, a side to this never before heard.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Yes! Charlotte knocks on the pantry door.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Go! Away! Skeeter slams the door.

Speaker: miss stein
Dialogue: Who was that?

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: My mother. She just dropped by to-

Speaker: miss stein
Dialogue: Look, no maid in her right mind would ever tell you the truth. That's a hell of a risk in a place like Jackson, Mississippi. I watched them try to integrate your bus station on the news. Oy! They jammed fifty-five Negroes in a jail built for four. Skeeter panics.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I already have a maid. Skeeter can't believe what just came out of her mouth. Miss Stein rises and sits on the edge of her desk.

Speaker: miss stein
Dialogue: Really? A negro maid has already agreed to talk to you? Skeeter blinks hard. No turning back now.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am...

Speaker: miss stein
Dialogue: Well...I suppose I could read what you come up with. The book biz could use a little rattling.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: You'd do that?

Speaker: miss stein
Dialogue: I'm saying I'll let you know if it's even worth pursuing.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Oh, thank you, Miss Stein!

Speaker: miss stein
Dialogue: And for God's sake, you're a twenty- four-year-old educated woman. Go get an apartment. She hangs up.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: "Dear Miss Myrna, How do I remove the rings from my fat, slovenly husband's shirt collar when he is such a pig and sweats like one too..."

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Which one she want a get rid of? Them rings or the husband? Skeeter chuckles and shrugs her shoulders.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Build it just like the one at my house, right against the garage. The contractor nods. Lightning strikes, thunder cracks.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Aibileen, do you ever wish you could...change things? Aibileen turns slowly from the window.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Everthing's fine.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: My momma fired Constantine. Thank you for telling me that.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: I never tolt you that! Aibileen jumps up as another crack of thunder sounds out.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Aibileen, I have an idea...Something I want to write about...But I need your help. Skeeter rises.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: You know what'd happen to me if Miss Leefolt knew I was tellin' stories on her?

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I was thinking we wouldn't tell her. The other maids will have to keep it secret, too.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Other maids?

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I was hoping to get four or five. To really show what it's like in Jackson. To see what y'all get paid, the babies, the bathrooms, the good and the bad. Aibileen shakes her head.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: They set my cousin Shinelle's car on fire just cause she went down to the voting station.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: A book has never been written like this, Aibileen.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: `Cause they's a reason. I do this with you, I might as well burn my own house down. Bam! The front door slams shut.

Speaker: raleigh
Dialogue: I put up with the new clothes and all the damn trips to New Orleans, but this takes the goddamn cake!

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: It'll confuse Mae Mobley if she sees Aibileen going inside. And we can't risk her health.

Speaker: raleigh
Dialogue: Great! Mae Mobley can just go to college in that bathroom, too.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Honey, Hilly's covering the cost...and said you can just do William's taxes to pay her back.

Speaker: raleigh
Dialogue: We don't take orders from the Holbrooks!

Speaker: raleigh
Dialogue: Skeeter? How you doing?

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Fine.

Speaker: raleigh
Dialogue: Fix me a sandwich, Aibileen. Raleigh storms out as Elizabeth charges into the kitchen.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Aibileen, Mae Mobley's crying her eyes out! Aibileen runs off. Elizabeth sees Skeeter and tries to compose herself.

Dialogue: You're making it a lot hotter flapping your arm like that. Minny stops and begins squirming with discomfort. Missus Walters notices her looking out to the garage bathroom. Lightning strikes. Leaves blow across the yard. Hilly plops down in a chair with a candle.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: That should do it. Minny, go get me and Momma some iced tea. Minny hesitates. She gulps.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Uh...Miss Hilly?

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Never mind. As Minny turns, Missus Walters calls out to her.

Speaker: missus walters
Dialogue: You go on ahead and use the guest bath, Minny. It's okay.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Oh, for crying out loud. It's just a little rain. She can go get an umbrella up in William's Study!

Speaker: missus walters
Dialogue: I believe she was working for me before you dragged us both here. Minny looks outside just as wind slams an aluminum lawn chair against the garage bathroom. Boom! Another crash of thunder. Large hail stones begin falling in the yard.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: I'm gone get your tea.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: MINNYYYY, are you in there?

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am...

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Are you sitting down? Minny gets up quickly and flushes the toilet. Hilly beats on the door.

Dialogue: Hurry, Aibileen. Mae Mobley's up, and I'm off to the doctor. Aibileen reaches behind and flushes the toilet. Mae Mobley gets excited and points to the garage bathroom.

Dialogue: Aibee bafroom, Momma! Mae Mobley walks toward the bathroom and calls out.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: No!

Dialogue: Be right there, Baby Girl. Aibileen pulls up her panty-hose.

Dialogue: Afternoon, Aibileen. Aibileen nods nervously, looking at the other domestics.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: You got some "Miss Myrna" questions for me?
