Dialogue: No. Yule May and others board. Skeeter grabs Aibileen's arm.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am. The bus pulls away.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Please let me interview you. I know it's scary, but I really believe this has to be done. We'll be careful.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: This already ain't careful, Miss Skeeter. You not knowing that is what scares me most. I'm sorry. Skeeter hands Aibileen a piece of paper with her phone number written on it. Aibileen turns and walks off down the sidewalk.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Oh, Aibileen! I went and did it now! Minny wraps a hand up in the phone cord.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Everbody know you honest, Minny.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Oh, but I got her back...I did something awful, Aibileen.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: What you did?!

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: She got what she deserve, Aibileen. But, now I ain't gone never get no work again...Leroy gone kill me. Minny's husband, LEROY, 40, approaches behind Minny. Minny slowly turns...

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Minny! She can't bear to listen and hangs up the phone. She sees Skeeter's phone number taped to the wall. Aibileen's breath becomes heavy. Anger wells inside her. She picks up the phone again and begins to dial.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I parked way up on State Street and caught a cab here like you asked.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Got dropped two streets over? Skeeter nods.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Aibileen, I now know it's against the law for us to meet like this. Skeeter stares Aibileen up and down. Aibileen self- consciously flattens our her dress.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Thank you. Aibileen motions for Skeeter to sit on a narrow sofa behind a coffee table covered in hand-tatted lace. A tray holds a teapot, two cups that don't match and cookies resting on folded napkins. As Aibileen pours the tea, her hand shakes.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I've never been in a colored person's home before. I think we're both doing great. This tea is really nice. Aibileen watches as Skeeter takes a bite of the cookie.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Miss Skeeter, What if...What if you don't like what I got to say? About white peoples?

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I...this isn't about my opinion. It doesn't matter how I feel.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: You gone have to change my name. Mine, Miss Leefolt's, everbody's.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Everybody? So, you know other maids who might be interested? Aibileen is quiet for a moment. She shakes her head.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: It gone be hard.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: What about Minny?

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Minny got her some stories, sho nuff. But, she ain't real keen on talking to white peoples right now.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: What does it feel like, to raise a white child when your own child's at home, being...looked after by somebody else?

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: It feel...Uh. Aibileen glances up to the framed picture of Treelore.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Is that your son?

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am. He dead two years now. Got run over at the lumber yard. Lungs were crushed.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I'm so sorry. That's horrible. And, Aibileen, you don't have to call me "ma'am." Not here anyway. Aibileen nods. Skeeter stares at her list of questions.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: I'm sorry, I- Aibileen covers her mouth with her hand. Skeeter becomes disgusted with herself.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: No, I am. She pulls out a stack of Miss Myrna letters.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: I thought I might write my stories down and read them to you.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Well, sure I guess.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: It no different than writing down my prayers.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: You don't say your prayers aloud?

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Prayer like electricity. It keep life going. Writing it down make it more powerful. Lot a ailing, sick peoples in this town.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I'm sure.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: I didn't get a chance to pray for Treelore.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Oh, Aibileen.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: But he'd like we's doing this. He always said we gone have a writer in the family one day...After my prayers last night, I got some stories down too. Skeeter nods. Aibileen opens her notebook and reads.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: It just ate him up, so one time I told him it cause I drank too much coffee. Oh, law, you should a seen his face.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: This is great. You have no idea how much I appreciate this...But I just have to ask. What changed your mind?

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: We're running behind on our "coat drive," girls. So hurry up and clean out those closets...But our Christmas Benefit, however, is right on schedule as y'all have already filled all our baked goods raffle slots. The girls applaud, turning to each other with praise.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: I gave that to you myself!

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I, ah...Well, I-

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Would you please stand, Skeeter? As Skeeter rises, several women shake their heads.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I'll have it in there soon. Skeeter glances at the initiative tucked in her satchel.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Hilly? Do you need a ride? Hilly shakes her head with little emotion.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: He's coming! Oh, Skeeter, he's definitely coming this time. This Saturday night.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Oh, Hilly, he's cancelled twice before. Maybe it's a sign.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Don't you dare say that!

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: You know I won't be his type. Hilly grabs Skeeter by the shoulders.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: It's your time, Skeeter. And damnit, I'm not going to let you miss this just because your mother convinced you you're not good enough for somebody like him.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Eat up, Girl. Miss Woodra's like to not feed ya on try-out day. Sugar takes a bite of toast.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: Hey there! I'm Celia Rae Foote. Aibileen said you'd be on time. Minny looks down disapprovingly to Celia's bare feet.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: No, thank you. I'm Minny Jackson... You...cooking something?

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: One of those upsidedown cakes from the magazine. It ain't workin' out too good. Come on in.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: What in the hell- Minny catches herself.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: I guess I have some learnin' to do.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: Johnny's momma wouldn't let me decorate a thing. If I had my way, this house would have wall to wall white carpet with gold trim and none of this old stuff. Minny spies a framed battle-worn Confederate flag complete with bullet holes.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Where you from? Celia lowers her head in shame...

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: Sugar Ditch. It's near Memphis.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: I know Sugar Ditch. My cousin live there. Celia changes the subject.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: Let's go meet Oscar! Celia grabs Minny's hand. Annoyed, Minny pulls it away.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: Johnny's granddaddy shot him up in Montana back in 1910 with Teddy Roosevelt. Celia points to fifteen guns mounted behind Oscar.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: When you gone have some chillins, start fillin' up all these beds? Celia swallows hard. She places her hand on her stomach.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: I'm pregnant now. Minny steps back and surveys Celia.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Gone be eatin' for two. Double the cookin'. Celia slumps her shoulders as she looks around the house.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: I know it's an awful lot to do. Five other maids have already turned me down...Can I at least give you some bus money?

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: When you hear me say I don't wanna clean this house?

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: What? So...You'll do it?! Before Minny can nod. Celia throws her arms around her. Minny backs away.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: No huggin', now. No huggin'.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: I'm sorry. This is my first time hiring a maid.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: We got to talk about some things first. I work Sunday through Friday. Celia bites her pinky nail.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: You can't come at all on weekends.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Okay. What time you want me here?

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: After eight, and you have to leave at four.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Okay. Now what your husband say you can pay? Celia looks away.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: Johnny doesn't know I'm bringing in help.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: And what's Mr. Johnny gone do if he comes home and finds a colored woman up in his kitchen?

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: It's not that I'd be fibbing. I just want him to think I can do this on my own...I need some help `til I get the hang of it. I need a maid.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: A course you do. Last one done got shot in the head. Minny sniffs the air.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: Oww! Dawgonit! She drops the burnt cake on the floor.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: You can't use no wet towel on a hot pan. Minny grabs a dry towel and picks up the cake.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: I'm off, Aibileen. Don't forget Raleigh wants pot roast tonight.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am. Aibileen's eyes narrow.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: I reckon I'm ready...to talk about Miss Leefolt now. Skeeter stops typing and looks up. She nods.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Where are you going, Skeeter? Skeeter turns.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Bible study.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: On a Saturday night?

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Momma, God doesn't care what day of the week it is. Skeeter walks out the back door as Charlotte shakes her head.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Miss Leefolt be spending so much time keeping up with the society ladies, she done forgot the child she got now. Just then Minny barges through the kitchen back door.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Aibileen! Minny stops cold in her tracks at the sight of Skeeter.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: We all working for the same thing.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I want to show her perspective...so people might understand what it's like from your side.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Well it's a real Fourth of July picnic.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I know, Minny. Maybe things might

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: What law's gonna say you gotta be nice to your maid? And another thing, I don't want my children going to school with white kids. And I don't care a thing about votin.' Only thing black mens get elected to is Deacon of the church.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: You don't have to do this, Minny.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: You damn right I don't! You two givin' me the heart palpitations. Minny storms out the back door. Skeeter looks like she might get sick.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: And that was a good mood. Minny immediately storms back in the kitchen.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: All right...I'm gone do it. I just want to make sure you know this ain't no game we're playing here. Skeeter nods, trembling as Minny slides a chair in the middle of the kitchen and sits.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Let's begin...begin with...with where you were born. Aibileen grabs her notebook and begins writing.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Belzoni, Mississippi on my great- auntie's sofa. Next!

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: I put the green beans in first, then I go on and get the pork chops going cause, mmm-mmm, I like my chops hot out the pan. Just as Aibileen fills the first notebook, Skeeter hands her another from her satchel.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: "Oh, Minny, I'm gone give you a week paid vacation." Now, I ain't had no paid vacation in my life. A week later, I come back and they'd moved to Mobile. "Miss Lazy Fingers" scared I'd find a new job before she moved... Minny spins around to Aibileen with sudden realization...

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: I know, but it hard, Minny. Mind racing, Minny flies out the door without a word. Aibileen turns to Skeeter.

Speaker: miss stein
Dialogue: I like this "Sarah Ross." She can kvetch but not complain too much.

Speaker: miss stein
Dialogue: And this "Bertha"...she's got chutzpah. I'll give her that.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: So...you liked it?

Speaker: miss stein
Dialogue: Eugenia, Martin Luther King just invited the country to march with him in D.C. this August. This many negroes and whites haven't worked together since "Gone with the Wind."

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Does this mean you'll publish it?

Speaker: miss stein
Dialogue: I never said that. My advice is to write it fast before this civil rights thing blows over. I need it by New Year's, and don't send me anything more until you have twelve maids.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Twelve?

Speaker: miss stein
Dialogue: At least.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Aibileen and I done asked everbody we know. Thirty-one maids. Everbody too scared, think we crazy...

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Then we might as well stop!

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: I got plenty a stories, Miss Skeeter. Just write`em down and invent a maid that said it. We already making up everbody's name. Make up the maids, too. Skeeter jumps up from her chair.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: We can't do that! Aibileen and Minny lean back.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Don't give up on us, Miss Skeeter. Skeeter softens and sits back down.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I'm sorry. Thank you both for trying.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: What can you cook? Minny dips pieces chicken in an egg wash, then drops them in a paper bag. A puff of flour rises out of the bag.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: I can cook corn pone, boil potatoes, and do grits. Minny bursts out laughing.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Well, I reckon if there's anything you ought to know `bout cooking... Minny holds up a can of Crisco.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: How pretty. Looks like frosting. Minny rolls her eyes and hands Celia the bag of Chicken.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Shake that. Celia starts shaking the bag.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: This is fun!

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: Looks so good! I'm starved. Aggravated, Minny stands.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: You supposed to eat in the dining room, Miss Celia. That how it works. Minny grabs Celia's plate.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: I'm fine right here, Minny. Minny sits back down with a sigh. Celia touches her arm.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Miss Celia, you got a lot more to be grateful for than me. A car is heard pulling up in the driveway. Minny panics.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: Oh, no! Hide! Minny slides down underneath the kitchen table.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Miss Celia, I ain't playin' around no more! He gone catch me here and shoot me dead right here on this no- wax floor! You gots to tell him. Ain't he wondering how the cooking so good?

Speaker: celia foote
Dialogue: You're right. Maybe we ought to burn the chicken a little. The doorbell rings. Celia runs off to answer.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Minny don't burn chicken.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: This is bound to work, Sweetie. It even smells expensive. She begins twisting Skeeter's hair into gooey spikes.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I feel the hope in your fingers. Skeeter resembles a papier mach starfish.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: How can you not know his last name?

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: He's William's cousin. That's all I know.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: That's just so sweet of Hilly. Charlotte takes a drag from her cigarette, then lifts up a silver machine complete with power cord and rubber hose.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: What is that?!

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: The Shinolator! It cost eleven dollars. I'm a good mother. Charlotte puts a shower cap device on Skeeter's head and reads from the Shinolator manual.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Two hours?! Charlotte flips a switch and takes another drag. The machine groans to life. Skeeter's cap inflates.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: I'll have Pascagoula bring you a magazine. Skeeter snatches her mother's cigarette and takes a drag.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Thanks, Constantine. Do you think this dress is cute? Skeeter holds the magazine up to Pascagoula. Only now does she realize what she's said and done.

Speaker: pascagolua
Dialogue: I knew Constantine. She was a mighty fine woman.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Holy shit.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: You've shrunk five inches. You'll be able to wear heels tonight. Charlotte looks down to the huarache shoes on Skeeter's feet and rushes to the closet.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: He's meeting me at Hilly's. Can I take the Cadillac?

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: We promised Carlton the Cadillac tonight. So, William's cousin will just have to come get you himself.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I'll take the truck.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: It's hooked to the motor grader.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I'll drive slow.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Don't mope. Remember to smile! Skeeter floors it. Charlotte runs faster.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: With your daddy's endorsement, I can win that Senate seat. Stuart feigns interest.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: I'll talk to him. Ice slams against Stuart's teeth as he downs his drink. Hilly pats William's leg then turns with concern to a grandfather clock announcing half past the hour. The front door flies open. Skeeter enters completely out of breath and sweaty. Her HAIR HAS TRIPLED IN SIZE. She waves.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Hey. As Hilly races toward Skeeter, William and Stuart stand. Stuart is as tall as he is handsome.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Boys, we'll be right back. Y'all talk about quarterbacks or something. Yule May, get Miss Skeeter a Coca Cola. Yule May runs off. Hilly pulls Skeeter down the hall.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Skeeter, you don't even have on lipstick! Skeeter dabs her armpits.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: It was so goddamn awful. I hit a cat. Hilly sprays Final Net.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Well...What do you think of him? Skeeter applies lipstick. Hilly removes the rollers.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: He looks handsome. Skeeter stands up and does a twirl for Hilly.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Seven.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Really?! Seven? Hilly nods, lets out a little squeal.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Honey, you're beautiful. Just go on out there...you're gonna do great. It's your time, Skeeter. I just know it. Hilly hugs Skeeter.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: You want a drink?

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Just water, please.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: THANKS?! So...you went to Alabama? Stuart nods. Hilly rolls her eyes.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: "Roll Tide." We still love him. Hilly pinches Stuart on the cheek.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Now you're in the oil business. Hilly says you're a rigsite leader.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: The money's good. If that's what you really want to know.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: That's not what I- Skeeter and Hilly watch as Stuart's and William's eyes fix on the front of the restaurant. Celia and Johnny have entered. Celia wears a tight green dress and the reddest lipstick ever put in a tube.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: Isn't that your old boyfriend, Hilly? Johnny Foote? Hilly scowls.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: William! The Lieutenant Governor just walked in. Hilly jumps up and pulls William away. The waiter returns with Stuart's drink and the water backs.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: So, what do you do with your time?

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I write a...a domestic maintenance column for the Jackson Journal. Stuart smirks, taking a huge sip of his drink.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: You mean housekeeping? Skeeter nods and grabs her water.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: We'd love your support on election day! Celia and Johnny walk up. Hilly stiffens.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Hilly, you look lovely tonight.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Thank you, Johnny.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: William, have you ever met Celia? William steps forward and shakes Celia's hand.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: Nice to meet you. Hilly grabs the crook of William's arm.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Sweetie, we need to go order our dinners. Celia musters up all the courage inside her.

Speaker: celia foote
Dialogue: Hilly, did you ever get the messages that I've been calling you?

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: I did not.

Speaker: celia foote
Dialogue: Well, I would love to help with the benefit. I have a lovely hand if you need invitations addressed.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: "Save the dates" were mailed weeks ago...You didn't get one? Celia shakes her head.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: Sounds like a ploy to find a husband...becoming an expert on keeping house.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Well, you must be a genius. You figured out my whole scheme. Skeeter fumes as Hilly and William return and sit.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: What'd we miss?

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: Isn't that what you women from Ole Miss major in? Professional husband hunting?

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I'm sorry, but were you dropped on your head as an infant? Stuart blinks and then smiles, somewhat impressed. Desperate to change the subject, Hilly claps her hands.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Who? Is? Hungry? Skeeter stands.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Not me! A kiss from God couldn't turn this `frog' into a `prince.' Tables begin to stare.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: Or you a `princess,' Sweetheart! As Skeeter walks away, she purposefully slides her purse into a glass of water, knocking it over into Stuart's lap.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Run on, now, Yule May. Got a big crowd coming for Miss Leefolt's baby shower.

Speaker: yule may
Dialogue: Miss Hilly, I would like to ask you and Mister William something. Hilly lowers her paper and nods. Yule May begins wrenching her hands.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Okay... Only now does William lower his paper.

Speaker: yule may
Dialogue: We are short seventy-five dollars on one of the tuitions. William stands up, kisses Hilly on the cheek.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: Well, I'm late. Gotta go. William leaves.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Go on...

Speaker: yule may
Dialogue: Now...We're faced with having to choose. Which son gets to go...if we don't find all the money. Hilly draws in a deep breath as does Yule May.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: That's not working for free, Yule May. That's paying off a debt.

Speaker: yule may
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: As a Christian, I'm going to do you a favor. Yule May's eyes widen as a hopeful smile forms.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: That's her. Aibileen's mouth drops open at the sight of Celia's shorts and tight sweater. Celia is having trouble selecting produce.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Miss Celia just don't see `em. The lines. Not between us, Miss Hilly, nobody. Aibileen just nods.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: You gone accuse me a philosophizing.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: I ain't afraid a no philosophy.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: I don't believe in lines anymore. Lines is in our heads `cause people like Miss Hilly try to make us believe they there. Celia squeezes a canteloupe with another scared maid.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Oh, they there. I know. I get punished for crossing them.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Lotta of folk think if you talk back to your husband, you crossed a line...need to be punished.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: You know I ain't studying no line like that.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Cause it ain't there. `Cept in Leroy's head. Lines between black and white ain't there either. Minny and Aibileen watch as Celia exits the store with her groceries and prances toward her car.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: So, I ain't crossing no line if I tell Miss Celia she ain't good enough for Miss Hilly? Tell her she ain't in Miss Hilly's league?

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: All I'm saying is kindness don't have no boundaries. Just then, MYRLIE EVERS, 30,  approaches the bus stop with her three Children. SONS, 10 and 3, and a

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: No. You got me. A bus pulls up and the doors open. Minny, Aibileen and the other maids step aside to let the Evers family board first.

Speaker: mae mobley
Dialogue: Mae Mo hungry, Momma. Elizabeth turns to Mae Mobley but never gets up.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: She's always hungry. All the women laugh except for Skeeter.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: You know she can hear you, Elizabeth? Elizabeth looks down to her plate. Aibileen sets down the scraper and kneels down to Mae Mobley.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: I'm on cut you some cake, Baby.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Aibileen, we gave that scraper to Hilly and William for their wedding present. Chantilly!

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: It so pretty. Hilly begins bouncing William Jr. on her knee.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Aibileen, are you enjoying your new bathroom over at Elizabeth's? Hilly nods with a tight smile and glances to the ground at Skeeter's red satchel.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Separate but equal. That's what Ross Barnett says, and you can't argue with the Governor.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Not in Mississippi. Birthplace of modern day government. Hilly narrows her eyes at Skeeter and turns to Aibileen.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Aibileen, did you know that me and Mister Holbrook arranged for that bathroom? Sent the boys over and the equipment, too. Hilly stays on Aibileen, waiting for her to say something. Skeeter fumes, hoping Aibileen doesn't say it.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am...And I thank you. Hilly smiles and nods.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Well...You. Are. Welcome. Hilly shoots Skeeter a last look. William Jr. leans into Hilly and hugs her.

Speaker: yule may
Dialogue: May I get you something?

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: No, thanks...

Speaker: yule may
Dialogue: I know what you want to ask, Miss Skeeter. Aibileen and Minny already did. Yule May closes the kitchen door.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I understand.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Ah...Yule May was just telling me how excited she was that her boys were going to go to college.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Is that true, Yule May?

Speaker: yule may
Dialogue: Yes, Ma'am. Skeeter notices that Hilly is holding the booklet of Jim Crow laws in her hand.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Did you also ask Miss Skeeter if you could borrow money?

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Of course not, Hilly! Hilly approaches Skeeter.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Skeeter, I'm starting to think you're intentionally not putting my initiative in the newsletter. Eyes down, Yule May hurries out of the kitchen.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Not at all. I'm just so busy right now with Mom.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Skeeter...I'm sorry about your mother. And I know you must be so worried. Hilly holds up the Jim Crow booklet.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: My dad had me get that for him.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: I mean, around your friends is one thing...But, believe it or not, there are real racists in this town! If the wrong person caught you with this...you'd be in serious trouble. Skeeter snatches the booklet from Hilly.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Thanks, Hilly! And thanks for going through my things.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Skeeter!

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: What?!

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Don't panic, but there's a very tall man named Stuart here for you.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: He's a drunken asshole, Mother. You wouldn't like him. Charlotte pulls a sun dress out of Skeeter's closet.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Skeeter, love and hate are two horns on the same goat. And, you need a goat!

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Stuart, would you like a cocktail? Skeeter shoots her mother a "What the..." look.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: No, Ma'am. Little too early.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Ha! Charlotte moves on.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: What's your last name, Stuart?

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: Whitworth.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Hmm...Where are you from?

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: Natchez.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Really? Well, I know a Whitworth from Natchez...But he's a Senator up in Washington.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: Yes, Ma'am. That's my daddy.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Who is?

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: Senator Whitworth. That's my father. Charlotte's jaw drops to her string of pearls.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Really? Stuart nods. Charlotte stands, flustered yet joyful.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: Look. I know it was a few weeks back, but I came here to say I'm sorry for the way I acted.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Who sent you? William or Hilly?

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: Neither. I was rude, and I've been thinking about it a lot.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Well, I haven't. So, just go.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: Now, look. I told Hilly I wasn't ready to go out on any date. I wasn't even close to ready. Stuart shoves his hands in his pockets like a boy.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Actually, I don't. I've never dated anyone before. Stuart looks up and starts laughing loudly.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: Well! That must be it then.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: I've never met a woman that said exactly what she was thinking.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I've got plenty to say...

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: Would you like to...come downtown with me and have dinner? We could talk... We could listen to each other this time.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I can't think of anything worse. Stuart looks down and nods.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: Then, I'm sorry. That's what I came to say and...I said it. Stuart turns and walks towards his car, self-consciously weaving his strong fingers through his hair. Skeeter looks up to her mother's empty window and shouts out to Stuart.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Just give me a minute! Stuart turns.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: What do you want, Skeeter?

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I'll have a Co-cola. Lots of ice.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: No, I mean in life. What do you want? Only now does Skeeter notice the tray of champagne the waiter is holding. Stuart nods as two glasses are set before them. The waiter leaves.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I want to be a journalist. Maybe a novelist. Maybe both.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: I like that...I've been thinking about you. You're smart, you're pretty, you're...tall!

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Pretty?

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: Yes. And I read your column. Very informative.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Baby girl home.

Speaker: mae mobley
Dialogue: Me and Aibiee bafroom, Momma. Elizabeth runs over and yanks Mae Mobley off, popping her hard on the behind.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: It! Is! Not! Mae Mobley begins to cry. Aibileen watches as Elizabeth hiss- whispers and yanks Mae Mobley hard on the arm.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: I'm here, baby girl. Aibee's here. Aibileen kisses her on the cheek.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: One day this wise Martian come down to Earth to teach us people a thing or two.

Speaker: mae mobley
Dialogue: Martian? How big?

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Oh, he about six-two.

Speaker: mae mobley
Dialogue: What's his name?

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Martian Luther King.

Speaker: mae mobley
Dialogue: What did he look like?

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Looked just like us, nose, mouth, hair on his head. But, sometimes people looked at him funny and were just downright mean to him.

Speaker: mae mobley
Dialogue: Why Aibee? Why was they so mean?

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: `Cause he was green. Elizabeth suddenly barges into the living room.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Aibileen! Come on! We have to go help Hilly. Now! Come on! Elizabeth runs outside. Aibileen grabs Mae Mobley.

Speaker: mae mobley
Dialogue: Look! Look, Aibee. Hilly flies out of her house as a REPORTER snaps a picture of her.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Get out of here! Hilly pushes him in the bushes and runs up to Elizabeth.

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Y'all stay put. Let me find out what's going on. As the driver gets up, a WLBT-TV news truck whizzes by followed by a police motorcycle. Aibileen leans in the aisle and looks ahead. The driver returns. The young black man speaks up.

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Colored people off. White people lemme know where y'all are going. I'll get you as close as I can.

Speaker: white passenger
Dialogue: What's going on? Aibileen and the young man walk down the stairs.

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: I don't know. Some nigger got shot. Where you headed? The bus door shuts and the driver backs away.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: I be all right. My house is seven blocks from here.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Naw, thank ya. I'll be fine...Law, I hope this ain't as bad as- Aibileen turns to discover the young man is gone. She stares into the darkness. Scared, she begins to run. She cuts through a yard and trips over a hedge. She falls hard to her knees. Terrified, Aibileen begins to sob. She sees Minny's porch light and pulls herself up.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Aibileen! You okay? Aibileen nods, trying to compose herself.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: KKK shot him! Hour ago. Right in front a his children, Aibileen.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: We gone pray for the Evers. We gone pray for Myrlie. Minny raises her fists.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: We living in hell! We trapped. Our kids is trapped. Minny turns to Sugar.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: We gone be careful.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Hitch us to a pickup and drag us behind? Shoot me front a my kids?

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: We ain't doing civil rights with Miss Skeeter. We just tellin' stories like they really happen. Minny and Aibileen grab hands and squeeze hard.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: You a fool, old woman. A fool! Aibileen hugs Minny.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: You are sick. Do not speak to me. Do not look at me. Don't say hello to my children. How long had you been planning to humiliate my family?

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: That's not it, Hilly.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: You thought you were so clever, didn't ya? But I've already installed three of those old toilets in people's garages.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Technically, it was a typo, Hilly.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: I intend to tell Stuart he's ruining his reputation by associating with you. Jolene's yard boy saw you hanging around the colored bus stop.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I wasn't hanging-

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: I guess your car was in the shop? Skeeter looks away.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Hilly, just who is that pound cake money being raised for, anyway? Hilly rolls her eyes.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: "The Starving Children of Africa." Skeeter nods and walks away. Hilly shouts out.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Miss Celia?

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Miss Celia, you in here? Minny hears running water and muffled crying behind the bathroom door. She presses her ear to the door.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: You mess up your hair coloring again? I helped you fix it last time, got it back real pretty.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Miss Celia! Celia aimlessly moves the blood around with a wash cloth.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: There's so much blood. Why is there so much blood this time? Minny crawls over, peers into the toilet bowl and gags.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Keep your head down.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Give her another pill if she gets too agitated. There'll be more bleeding, but don't call me unless it's heavy. Minny nods as the doctor leaves.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: We got married because I was pregnant. But it slipped out too.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: That's just God's way. Next one's gonna catch.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: Johnny wants kids now. I thought if I was real still, brought somebody in to do the house and cooking, maybe I'd hold on to this one. Oh, Minny, what's he gonna do with me?

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: He gone have to get over this. He needs to know this takes time.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: He doesn't know about this one, or the one before... Minny turns to Celia, stunned by this revelation.

Speaker: celia foote
Dialogue: Minny, you know how to play bridge, don't you? Minny nods.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am. I used to help Missus Walters practice.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Happy Birthday! Mae Mobley two today! Mae Mobley laughs as Aibileen sets down the grits.

Speaker: mae mobley
Dialogue: Mae Mobley three!

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: You sure is, Baby Girl. Blow'em out `fo they run up in your grits. Mae Mobley blows out the candles.

Speaker: mae mobley
Dialogue: How old are you, Aibiee?

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Fifty-three.

Speaker: mae mobley
Dialogue: Do you get burfdays?

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Gone be fifty-four next week.

Speaker: mae mobley
Dialogue: Do you have some babies?

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: I gots seventeen of `em.

Speaker: mae mobley
Dialogue: Where are the babies?

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: They all over town.

Speaker: mae mobley
Dialogue: Aibee...You're my real mama.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Now, you know who your momma is.

Speaker: mae mobley
Dialogue: I'm your real baby, Aibee. Those other ones are just pretend.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Okay. First order of business. We're updating our newsletter. Hilly stares right at Skeeter who sits alone in the back.

Speaker: jolene french
Dialogue: I nominate Hilly Holbrook. Jolene looks back and snarls at Skeeter.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Jolene, you're the sweetest thing!

Speaker: other members
Dialogue: I second. I third. All in favor of Hilly, say "Aye." The room erupts.

Speaker: members
Dialogue: Aye! Skeeter's ousting took less than ten seconds. Elizabeth secretly turns to Skeeter from a few rows ahead.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Honey, would you like me to drop you off at bridge club on the way to my doctor's appointment?

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Everything okay? Elizabeth looks back. Her belly is huge.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Shhh! There's a knock at door.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: They made me stand there like the vacuum man. Why, Minny? Minny freezes, keeping her face on the peas.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Because they know about you getting knocked up by Mister Johnny. They mad you married one a they mens. Especially since Mister Johnny and Miss Hilly had just broke up, too.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: So, Hilly probably thinks I was fooling around with Johnny while they were still going steady.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Missus Walters says Miss Hilly still sweet on Mister Johnny, too. Celia suddenly slaps her thigh with excitement.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: No wonder! They don't hate me...They hate what they think I did!

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: They hate you cause they think you're white trash! And don't be takin' pies to those women!

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: Well, I'm just going to have to let Hilly know I'm not a boyfriend stealer. In fact, I'll tell her Friday night at the benefit. Celia rises and smiles like she just cured cancer.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Now, Miss Celia...please don't be going to that benefit. Celia gets some ice out of the fridge.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: That looks bad.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: I got to get my work done.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: I know you didn't fall in the tub, Minny. Let me take a look. Celia grabs Minny's hand. Minny pulls away. Just then Johnny pulls up in the driveway. Celia and Minny turn to the window, then spring into action.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: What's wrong?

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Yule May in prison, Miss Skeeter. Gone be there four years. Minny shouts out across the kitchen.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Hilly Holbrook been sent from the devil to ruirn all our lives.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Please! A nigra walks in a pawn shop with a ring of such size and clarity. It took'em all of five minutes to figure out where she worked. Hilly leads the girls' nods of acknowledgement.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I'll ask daddy to get her a good lawyer.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: She had a lawyer. A white lawyer! But Miss Hilly friends with the judge's wife. Whole thing took two days. Arrested on Tuesday, in the state pen by Wednesday.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: The church gone send them boys to college. Gone pass the plate `til they graduate... The women part, making way as Aibileen leads Skeeter to a seat at the kitchen table. PEARLY, 58, sits next to Skeeter and touches her arm.

Speaker: pearly
Dialogue: I'm on help with your stories. Another WOMAN walks over.

Speaker: black woman
Dialogue: I'm on help too. Another woman speaks from the living room.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Thank you. I don't know what to-

Speaker: pearly
Dialogue: Been there thirty-eight years and Miss Margaret still makes me put my hair up in a rag. Say she know coloreds don't wash theys hair. But, I love her. She love me too.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: I had been workin' for Miss Jolene's mother up `til she died. Then her daughter, Miss Nancy, asked me to come work for her. Miss Nancy a real sweet lady.

Speaker: callie
Dialogue: I used to take a shortcut ever day to work at Doctor Dixon's house. Cut through this farmer's lower forty to get there. One day, that farmer was waitin' on me with a gun, said he'd shoot me dead if I walk on his land again. Doctor Dixon went and paid that farmer double for two a those acres. Told him he `bout to start farmin' too. But he bought it just for me. So I could get to work easy. He did. Skeeter closes her eyes for moment. When she opens them she sees A VISION OF CONSTANTINE STANDING

Speaker: gretchen
Dialogue: All these colored women have been real nice, haven't they?

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Yes. Very nice.

Speaker: gretchen
Dialogue: Well, they hate you. You know this? Every little thing about you. But you're so dumb, you think you're doing them a favor. Skeeter and the other maids are taken aback.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: You don't have to do this.

Speaker: gretchen
Dialogue: You know the nicest thing a white woman's ever done for me? Gave me the heel of her bread. These women are playing a trick on you. They'll never tell you the truth!

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: You don't know what they've said.

Speaker: gretchen
Dialogue: Say it, lady, say the word you think every time one us stands in front of you. Nigger. Aibileen crosses over to Gretchen.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: That's enough, Gretchen.

Speaker: gretchen
Dialogue: You just as dumb as she is.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Get out a my house!

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Tell her to pour vinegar in her trash cans. Then them dogs will stay away. As Skeeter writes this down, someone walks onto Aibileen's front porch. Skeeter becomes worried. Aibileen looks to a wall clock and smiles. About a dozen letters and cards fall into a basket under the mail slot. Aibileen jumps up and starts sorting through the cards.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Well, happy birthday, Aibileen. You should have told me.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: And, from all over the county, my babies find they way home. Aibileen stops on one card in particular. She sits back down next to Skeeter.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: What?! Stuart throws his arm over Skeeter. Reality sinks in. Skeeter rolls over to find Stuart, eyes shut, smiling.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Morning, Sleepy Head.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Morning, Mom. Charlotte pulls out a dress and lays it on the bed, right on top of Stuart.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: I thought you could take me to the doctor this morning and then we could get some lunch afterwards.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Sure! Charlotte spies a LARGE TOE sticking out of the covers. It belongs to Stuart, but she assumes it's Skeeter's.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Or...we could...go straight to Fanny Mae's for a girl day.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Great! I'll get dressed.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: When did Stuart leave last night?

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Right after you went to bed.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Well, I hope he knows he's welcome to stay in Carlton's old room.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I'm not really ready for that yet.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: "Bird in the hand," Eugenia. Bird. In. The. Hand... Charlotte exits and shuts the door.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: Chirp. Chirp. Skeeter is mortified. Stuart sits up, grinning.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Oh my God! Stuart tries to kiss Skeeter. She resists.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: So is mine.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I love you, too. They kiss.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: Honey, I'm sorry, but I have to get down to the coast. Skeeter nods as Stuart kisses her.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: You, too. We hear Walter Cronkite's parting thoughts on JFK.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Are you okay?

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: The world done gone crazy, Miss Skeeter! And I'm scared! What if folks find out what we writing? Figure out Niceville really Jackson, and figure out who who?

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Aibileen. We've changed all the names. Aibileen snaps.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Y'all two gone sit there and tell me you one hundred percent without a doubt sure `bout all this?! Skeeter looks away..

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: No...So I been thinking...Maybe we need us some insurance. Skeeter look to Minny.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Nobody wanted to hire a sass- mouthing, thieving nigra, did they? Minny stands silent as Hilly finishes in three bites.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: I'm glad you like it. Hilly cuts another piece for herself.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: If...I take you back, I'll have to cut your pay five dollars a week. Not expecting this, Minny leans away from Hilly.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Take me back? Hilly takes an even bigger bite from the second slice.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: What do you put in here that makes it taste so good?

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: That good vanilla from Mexico... Minny's eyes narrow over a forced smile.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Momma can have a piece. Hilly slides the pie a little too fast down the counter toward Minny. Minny stops it before it falls to the floor.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: What did you say?

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: I said eat my shit!

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Have you lost your mind?! Minny moves toward Hilly.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: No. But you're about to, `cause you just did. Minny nods smugly as she looks down at Hilly's slice.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Did what? Missus Walters immediately gets it. She bursts out laughing so hard she has to lower herself to the floor.

Speaker: missus walters
Dialogue: Well, Hilly, that's what you get, I guess. And you didn't just eat one. You ate two slices! Hilly starts to hyperventilate as everything sinks in. As Minny leaves, Hilly runs to the sink and throws up.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: You trying to get yourself killed?!

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: No! I never planned to tell her! I just wanted to see her take a bite and leave so I could be done with her. Forever! She was never supposed to ask me back. Minny eyes narrow.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: It's too dangerous, Minny.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: We need insurance! Hilly Holbrook can't never let people know that pie story is about her.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Exactly! If people find out "The Terrible Awful" was you and Miss Hilly, then we in trouble. Trouble there ain't words for!

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Right! But don't you see? Miss Hilly gone go to her grave convincing people this book ain't about Jackson. Then we safe, insured! Minny gets up and walks toward Aibileen.

Speaker: miss stein
Dialogue: The last editor's meeting is December 17th. If you want a chance of this getting read, I need it in my hands by then.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: But that's in a week, Miss Stein!

Speaker: miss stein
Dialogue: Otherwise it goes in The Pile. You don't want it in The Pile.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Yes, Ma'am.

Speaker: miss stein
Dialogue: And you must get a piece in about the domestic who raised you. It'll add something personal to it. Skeeter nods with frustration.

Speaker: jolene
Dialogue: This is Jolene French reporting from the African Children's Benefit Ball, and I'm here with League President Miss Hilly Holbrook.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Thanks, Jolene... Three dozen servers stand in a line. Minny and Aibileen are among them. Tables are covered with items donated for the auction. On the baked goods table, Minny's famed chocolate pie promises to again be a big money maker. Celia and Johnny enter the ballroom. Celia wears a hideous, pink and silver sequined gown. As usual, Celia's breasts command attention. The room locks on Celia as specks of light bounce off her dress and jiggle across the ceiling. A TITILLATED OLD HUSBAND tips his martini onto his wife's shoe.

Speaker: old husband
Dialogue: Look at the jugs on that one!

Speaker: old wife
Dialogue: Bosoms are for bedrooms and breast- feeding. Not occasions of dignity. Celia downs a glass of champagne and leans into Johnny.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: Do you think I might have overdressed a little? It's supposed to be formal, but this looks like a funeral.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: You look gorgeous. Minny pulls Aibileen aside and points to Celia.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Look what she got on. Celia grabs more champagne from a passing server.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Lord have mercy. Ladies better hold onto they husbands tonight. Celia catches eyes with Minny. She smiles and nods quickly and then looks away, careful not to tip off Johnny of their relationship.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: There's Skeeter and that must be Stuart. He's handsome... Missus Walters?! Missus Walters enters wearing a floor-length blue beaded

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Hilly can throw her in a home, but she can't keep the taxis away.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: Well, hello, Elizabeth.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Hi. Elizabeth's homemade maternity ball gown resembles a velvet potato sack cinched with red ribbon.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: Those are lovely dresses.

Speaker: jolene
Dialogue: Yours too.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: Really?! I was worried I was a tad overdressed. Jolene reaches out an pats Celia's shoulder.

Speaker: jolene
Dialogue: Oh, no. You're just perfect. Elizabeth pulls Jolene away. Celia downs her drink.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Everybody enjoying their dinner? The room claps enthusiastically.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: Woo-hoo! Johnny grabs Celia by the arm and pulls her back down. Celia reaches for Johnny's glass of wine.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Honey, maybe you've had enough to drink. Try to eat your dinner.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: And have my stomach poke out?!

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Why, Johnny Foote. I'm surprised to see you here. Everybody knows you can't stand parties like this. Hilly squeezes the crook of his arm.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Celia wouldn't have missed this for anything.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Where is that wife of yours? Out selling hotdogs? Johnny looks away.

Speaker: jolene
Dialogue: I've got the list of winners!

Speaker: jolene
Dialogue: I hope you enjoy your new set of tires, Missus Atwell. Now, on to the baked goods. Jolene flips a page.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: What? I didn't bid on anything. Minny turns to find Hilly smiling at her tightly.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: Congratulations, Hilly! I didn't know you're a fan of Minny's pies. Hilly remains calm. Celia grabs Hilly's long sleeve.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Let me go! Hilly stands up and pulls away. A ripping sound cuts through the air. Celia stares at Hilly's torn cuff in her hands.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: Oh, God.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: I'm so sorry.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: I don't know what you-

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: -You liar! Who did you tell?! Jolene loses her place on the list. The room grows quiet but Celia is still yelling.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: Hilly, I got pregnant after you and Johnny broke up! The room echoes with Celia's words. Across the room, women's noses wrinkle.

Speaker: missus walters
Dialogue: Oh, shit.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Shut up, Mother. Stuart belts out with a laugh. Skeeter pinches his arm. Celia is mortified. Sweat beads on her forehead.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: Johnny never cheated on you...At least, not with me. Celia starts to breathe heavily. Her eyes start to water.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Johnny would never-

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: And I'm sorry I thought you'd be tickled to win that pie.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: You tell that nigra if she tells anybody, I will make her suffer. Horrified, Skeeter catches eyes with Minny and Aibileen. They all immediately look away. Johnny makes his way over. Celia holds her breath, shaking her head back and forth.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Celia, what's wrong, Honey?

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: Uh-oh. Celia leans over and vomits on the fleur-de-lis print carpet. The entire room gasps in horror.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Oh, shit! Johnny tries to pull Celia back. She pushes Johnny away and runs for the bathroom. He follows. Hilly marches over to Aibileen who is standing nearby.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Get that cleaned up before it starts to smell.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am.

Speaker: sugar
Dialogue: That big-boobed lady Momma works for was drunker than an Injun on payday. Upchucked in front a everbody! As the girls all laugh, Minny pops Sugar hard on the back of her head.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Don't you never let me hear you talking bad about the lady who puts food in your mouth. Clothes on your back! You hear me? Minny storms off.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Just come on home and stay with us tonight, Mother.

Speaker: missus walters
Dialogue: No thanks, I got a pie to eat. Hilly spins around and sees the pie.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: You throw that pie away right now!

Speaker: missus walters
Dialogue: I spent good money on this. Won it just for you...

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: You?! You signed me up? Missus Walters steps up to Hilly.

Speaker: missus walters
Dialogue: I may have trouble remembering my own name and what country I live in. But there's two things I can't seem to forget. That my own daughter threw me in a nursing home...And that she ate Minny's shit. Missus Walters winks at Hilly and ambles to a waiting taxi cab.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Ain't Mister Johnny gone wonder how dinner got on the table if you laid up in bed? Celia pulls the covers off her head and sits up a little.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: The way Hilly looked at me. Like I was trash on the road. Celia pulls a letter out from under the covers.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: She don't count. Don't judge yourself by the way she see you.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: I'm not right for this kind of life, Minny. I don't need a dinner table for twelve people.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: You gone leave your husband cause you threw up at some party? Celia sobs.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Miss Hilly thought you knew `bout "The Terrible Awful," that you were making fun a her. It's my fault she pounced on you. But if you leave Mister Johnny, then Miss Hilly done won the whole ball game. Then she done beat me, and she done beat you. Celia lies there. Minny's concerned she's said too much.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: Thank you. For telling me that.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: Hey, Honey.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Stuart! How are you calling me? Aren't you on the rig?

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: What if I told you I have twenty- four hours in New Orleans?

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Oh, Stuart.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I have to work.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: Work in the car. Jesus, Skeeter, it's a cleaning column.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I have a deadline, Sweetie. You should have asked me about this.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: I'm trying to be romantic...

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I'm sorry, Honey. I can't come. Stuart shakes his head and hangs up the phone.

Speaker: faye belle
Dialogue: I remember hiding with Miss Lilia in a steamer trunk while Yankee soldiers stomped through Master's house. We were both four. Eighty- five years later she died in my arms. We's were friends `til the end. Her grandson still pays my rent. Buys all my groceries too.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I have one more story to type, but other than that, we are done.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Law, look at all them pages. Two- hundred and sixty-six of `em.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Now we just wait and see? Hopin' Missus Stein publish it? Skeeter nods.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Mine. Aibileen looks at Skeeter.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: If your momma won't tell you, I reckon I will.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Have you been crying? You know that ages your skin, Dear.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Mother, I need to talk to you about Constantine.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Oh, Eugenia. That was so long ago.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Well, I have to speak to her.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Now, you look. I was good to Constantine. Oh, she talked back plenty of times, and I put up with it. But, Skeeter, she didn't give me a choice...

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: What...happened?

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: Watch out! With that, Charlotte stands up and slaps the table with her hand.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Get a hold of yourself, Constantine! Constantine slowly looks to Charlotte. Totally exhausted, she grips the casserole cart with both hands to steady herself.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: I told her she couldn't work here anymore and to go on home.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: How could you humiliate her like that?!

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: I didn't mean to.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Why didn't you help her?

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: I was upset. I didn't know what else to do.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: So you just threw her away? That woman did you the biggest favor of your life. She taught me kindness and self respect and you just threw her away like a broken appliance. Charlotte starts to cry. Skeeter isn't affected.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: I didn't throw her away, Skeeter. Your daddy went to her house the very next day to give her her job back. But she had already moved to Chicago. Left everything behind.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: `Cause she didn't have anything anymore. You broke her heart!

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Please don't do this to me, Skeeter. I feel terrible. And you have to remember, they're not like us. They are different. Charlotte gets defensive.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I needed somebody to look up to. Skeeter turns to leave.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: We finally found the address of her daughter in Chicago...so we sent Carlton up there to go get Constantine. Skeeter turns back to her mother.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: And?

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: When he got there...she was dead, Eugenia. I'm so sorry, Honey. Charlotte tries to comfort her. Skeeter rejects her mother's hand.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Why didn't y'all tell me all this?

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: I knew you'd blame me...when it wasn't my fault. It just happened, and it was so unfortunate. I'm sorry, Eugenia.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: When did she die? How long had she been in Chicago?

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Two weeks. Skeeter stands, never turning as she exits.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Come on, Miss Celia! Get out a that bed and let me in. It's twelve noon. I did all the shopping just like you asked. The door slowly opens. Celia steps out onto the porch, looking beautiful, still dressed tacky.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: What's all this?

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: I cooked it all by myself. I wanted to do something special. I wanted to say "thank you."

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Greens got just the right amount a hock taste to `em. That's a good pot liquor, Miss Celia. Who taught you to cook like this? Minny winks as she dunks a piece of corn bread in the greens.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: Are you happy, Minny?

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Why you ask such a funny question?

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: Are you?

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: A course I's happy. You happy too. Big house, big yard, good husband.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: You know, if I were you, I'd give it right back to him. I'd hit him over the head with a skillet and tell him to go straight to hell... Minny starts to protest but is tired of excuses.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Maybe I will. Celia jumps up.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: I almost forgot the dessert. Minny smiles softly as Celia disappears into the kitchen.

Speaker: show runner
Dialogue: Five, four, three, two, one.

Speaker: male host
Dialogue: Welcome back to "People Will Talk." And do we have something to talk about. Jolene has quite a book to review. Jolene shakes her head, visibly upset.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Why are you frowning, Jolene? Hilly leans over and taps her television.

Speaker: male host
Dialogue: It's called "The Help." A new book by an anonymous author. Aibileen jerks her head toward the television.

Speaker: celia
Dialogue: Look how cute that dress is.

Speaker: male host
Dialogue: Takes place in the fictional town of "Niceville." The book is dedicated to C and T. If you're out there C and T, we'd love to have you on the show because Niceville sounds like Jackson, if you ask me. The host starts laughing. Jolene snaps.

Speaker: jolene french
Dialogue: It's not Jackson! It's a disgrace to the South! A disgrace to good Southern women who've spent their lives taking care of their help.

Speaker: leefolt home
Dialogue: Smoke rises from the shirt Aibileen is ironing. She snaps to attention, pulls the iron off the burned shirt.

Speaker: male host
Dialogue: But did you read that ending?

Speaker: jolene french
Dialogue: I know I personally treat my help like family, and every one of my friends does the same.

Speaker: jolene french
Dialogue: Do not buy this book! Ladies of Jackson, do not support slander with your husband's hard earned- Poof! Jolene disappears by way of a Seal-Lily ice cream commercial.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Don't cut her off like that.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: What's that book called, Aibileen?

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: I...I wasn't paying attention.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I knew nothing about it. Miss Stein's P.R. Department called the station directly.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Ever maid callin' to say they white lady's gone and bought the book. They so scared.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: `One-arm-Earnestine' said Miss Leefolt brought a copy over to Miss Hilly in less than a hour. She better read it quick and start the "this ain't Jackson crusade."

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Don't count on it. In her one year at Ole Miss she never cracked a book.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Oh, she gone read it. Especially after that man made such a stink on the tee-vee. She gone read it.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: That month felt like a year. I missed you so much.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Me, too.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: Skeeter, I told Daddy I'm not going back on the rig. Stuart nonchalantly pulls out a ring from his front pocket and places it in Skeeter's lap. A huge diamond is surrounded by twelve small sapphires. Skeeter's smile quickly fades as she raises the ring.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Stuart...I have to tell you something.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: How about "yes?!" I had this with me down in New Orleans, you know. Skeeter touches Stuart's face.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I'm serious...and...you have to promise not to tell anyone.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: Hang on. Did you say `yes'?

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Yes. Stuart hugs Skeeter. She pulls back.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: Sure. You have my word.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: This is what you've been writing for the last twelve months?! What happened to the cleaning column?

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I did both.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: So, the talk in town? I said they were dead wrong. Told them you were too smart to get mixed up in anything like that. Skeeter reaches to calm him. He pulls away.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: Things are fine around here. Why stir up trouble?

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I'm not stirring up trouble, Stuart. Trouble's already here.

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: I guess it is. Skeeter grabs his arm.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I had to tell you. You needed to know. Stuart shakes his head and pulls away...

Speaker: stuart
Dialogue: I guess I don't really know you, Skeeter. And I can't marry somebody I don't know. Stuart looks down at the ring.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Just leave.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Skeeter?! Come in here, please. After a few moments, Skeeter enters.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: You okay? Can I get you anything?

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Come here, Eugenia. I want to tell you something.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Me, too.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: You go first.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Stuart proposed.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Finally!

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: You knew?

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Of course. He had to ask Daddy for your hand. She lifts Skeeter's ring hand. Seeing her bare finger, Charlotte's smile fades. Skeeter prepares for the worst.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Just say it.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: What did you do?!

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Nothing! Skeeter stands to walk away.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Young lady, I'm talking to you! Skeeter sits back down...

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Oh, Momma. Charlotte slaps her palms as if throwing the cancer away.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Too late. I tried calling Fanny Mae's so I could make your hair appointments for the next twenty years, but they wouldn't allow it. Charlotte raises Skeeter's ring finger.

Speaker: sugar
Dialogue: Momma, there's a white man at our door!

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Who there?

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Johnny Foote. Minny Jackson, I want to talk to you. Open up. Minny slowly opens the door. Johnny is all smiles.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Finally, I meet Minny Jackson... As Johnny enters, Minny raises the bat and swings. Johnny turns and stops the bat with his hand.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Please don't hurt me! My babies are in the house. Johnny drops the bat and pulls Minny up from the floor.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Calm down, girl. I'm not here to get you.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: When I finally confronted Celia about you, she told me about the baby. All of them. You saved her life.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: I don't know about that.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Well, I know the day you came to our house, she started getting better. And I'm not just talking about the cookin' either.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: You knew I was there?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Fried chicken and okra on the first night? Y'all should have at least put corn pone on the table.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: I couldn't make you eat anymore corn pone, Mister Johnny.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: Next morning, I snuck back up to the house, peeked in the window, and there you were. Given ol' Oscar a wipe down. Minny smiles for the first time.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: So I ain't losing my job?

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: You have a job with us for the rest of your life, if you want it.

Speaker: jolene french
Dialogue: I heard that Betty character might be Charlene.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: It's not Jackson, and that book is garbage. I bet the whole thing's made up by some nigra. Aibileen begins pouring coffee into Hilly's cup.

Speaker: jolene
Dialogue: Well, yes...But that's not odd is it? Happens all the time, right? A sudden realization washes over Jolene.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: The book is NOT ABOUT JACKSON! Aibileen spills a few drops of coffee on Hilly's plate. Hilly looks up to Aibileen slow and deliberate.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: We late? Looks like Bible study done already started.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: No. We ain't late.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Who we clappin' for? The woman laughs.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: Honey, we clappin' for you. The woman raises a copy of "The Help." Aibileen notices a copy of the book in each member's hand. Aibileen looks to Minny, realizing she's in on it. A REVEREND approaches, hands Aibileen a copy of the book.

Speaker: reverend
Dialogue: Aibileen, this is an important time for you and our church. We know you couldn't put your name in here, so we all signed our own. The Reverend then hands her a box wrapped in white paper, tied with a blue ribbon.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Churches over two counties signed our books. All for you and me. Aibileen points to the inside back cover.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: We did something. We did something good.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: It's beautiful. Skeeter closes the book and sets it down regretfully.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: What's wrong? Skeeter pulls a letter out of her purse.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I got a job offer from Harper and Row...in New York.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Congratulations!

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: That real good, Miss Skeeter.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I not taking it. I just wanted to share it with you both. There's no one else I can tell.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: What you mean you not takin' it? This is what you been dreaming of.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I can't leave you two right when things are getting bad from a mess I created. I set out to write a book to make white people thankful. But in the end, what we should say is "sorry."

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: If bad things happen, they ain't nothing you can do about it. And if they happen, at least now theys a reason behind it. A reason we can wrap our heads around and be proud of... Skeeter nods with little relief.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: You ain't got nothing left here but enemies in the Junior League. You done burned ever bridge there is. And you ain't never gone get another man in this town, and ever body know it. So don't walk your white butt to New York, RUN IT! Minny leans over, placing her hand on Skeeter's for the first time since knowing each other.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Go find your life, Miss Skeeter.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: What are you doing here? Hilly screams and throws her lit cigarette at Skeeter.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Don't you get an inch closer! Hilly's a mess. Her shirt is half tucked. Her shorts strain to contain a newly developed layer of fat. A horrible fever blister burns hot on Hilly's upper lip.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: You can't prove anything, Hilly.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: I one-hundred-percent know you wrote it `cause nobody else in town is as tacky as you. Those nigras of yours are in a lifetime of trouble.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Exactly who are you talking about? You don't know anything.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: I don't, do I? You tell Aibileen, the next time she wants to write about my dear friend Elizabeth...uh- huh. Remember her? Had you in her wedding? Let's just say, Aibileen ought to've been a little bit smarter before putting in the L- shaped crack in poor Elizabeth's dining table. And that nigra, Minny? Do I have plans for her.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Careful, Hilly. Don't give yourself away now.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: That was not me WHO ATE THAT PIE! Hilly storms up the porch steps. Skeeter follows.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: I did not invite you here! Skeeter yanks Hilly's arm hard.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: I've come to tell your mother what a hippie you've become. She's gonna be disgusted by you. Skeeter can't help but laugh.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: You're telling my mother on me? Hilly opens the door. Skeeter grabs her. They struggle.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Why, Hilly...It's been such a long time, Dear. Everything okay, you two? Hilly is shocked by Charlotte's frail appearance.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Missus Phelan, I'm...I'm here to-

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Hilly, you're a mess. Are you ill? Hilly self-consciously licks her fever blister.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Well, I...I didn't have time to get fixed up before-

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Darling, no husband wants to come home and see this. Charlotte peers closely at Hilly's cold sore.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Missus Phelan, I'm here-

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: You know, Hilly. If I didn't know any better, I'd say you've been eating too many...SWEETS? Hilly's face turns purple with embarrassment. Charlotte moves in for the kill.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Yes, Ma'am.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: Ma'am?

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Do you have plans tomorrow? Bible study? Anything like that?

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: No, Ma'am.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Good. We're going shopping. Skeeter lets out a big sigh of relief.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: I'm very proud of you, Eugenia.

Speaker: skeeter
Dialogue: How do you know about New York?

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: A friend of Constantine's told me. Charlotte reaches down and pulls up her copy of "The Help".

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: They fired Leroy last night! And when Leroy ask why, his boss say Mister Holbrook told him to do it. Said his nigger wife the reason.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Oh, Law!

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: He try to kill me with he bare hands! He threw the kids in the yard, lock me in the bathroom, and say he gone set the house on fire.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Where are you now?!

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: The gas station. I climbed out the window, and we all ran here.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: I'm on come there now.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: Wait, Aibileen...I'm pregnant.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Minny, now, you listen to me. That baby gone be fine, and you ain't never gone lose your job. Mister Johnny told you that hisself. They's more book money coming. Your baby ain't gone know about gettin' beat. You hear me? You free, Minny! You are free. Minny lets out a chuckle of relief and wipes her eyes.

Speaker: minny
Dialogue: I hear you... The Leefolt front door opens. Elizabeth calls out.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Good morning. Hilly licks her cold sore as she steps forward. She glides her hand across the L-shaped crack in the Elizabeth's table, drawing Aibileen's attention to it.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Aibileen, the silver I lent Elizabeth last week.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: It not polished good? Humidity been fighting me on polishing day.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: When you returned it, three pieces were missing out of the felt wrapper. A fork and two spoons.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Lemme...lemme go look in the kitchen, maybe I left some behind.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: You know as well as I do that silver's not in the kitchen. Aibileen turns to Elizabeth.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: You check in Mae Mobley's bed? She been putting things-

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Do you hear her, Elizabeth? She's trying to blame it on a toddler. Elizabeth won't look at Aibileen.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: I ain't stole no silver. Elizabeth whispers to Hilly.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: She says she doesn't have them.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Then it behooves me to inform you that you are fired, Aibileen. And I'll be calling the police. They know me. Mae Mobley enters the room.

Speaker: mae mobley
Dialogue: Aibee, my froat hurts. Mae Mobley coughs.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: I go get her some syrup, Miss Leefolt.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Elizabeth can take care of her child. Elizabeth looks to Hilly, appearing somewhat upset with this suggestion.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: I'll go get the couch syrup. Hilly glares at Aibileen as Elizabeth runs down the hall.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: I won't tolerate liars! Mae Mobley becomes scared and hides behind Aibileen's leg.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: I didn't steal no silver.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: I'm not talking about silver. I'm talking about those things you wrote about Elizabeth. Maybe I can't send you to jail for what you wrote, but I can send you to jail for being a thief. And your friend, Minny? That nigra's got a nice surprise coming to her. Johnny Foote listens to what I say. She's as good as- Aibileen shouts, interrupting Hilly.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Woman!...I know something about you. Don't you forget that. Hilly narrows her eyes.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Nobody would believe something you wrote.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: I don't know. Already sold a lot a books. Fear floods into Hilly's eyes.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: Get out of here!

Speaker: mae mobley
Dialogue: Don't go, Aibiee! Aibileen kneels down as Elizabeth returns with the syrup.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Baby, you need to get back to bed. You got a fever.

Speaker: mae mobley
Dialogue: Noooo! Don't go, Aibee. Please don't leave.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: I gots to, Baby. I am so sorry.

Speaker: mae mobley
Dialogue: Why? Are you going to take care of another little girl?

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: No, Baby, that's not the reason. I don't want to leave you, but...It's time for me to retire. You my last little girl.

Speaker: mae mobley
Dialogue: Noooo!

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Baby Girl, I need you to remember ever thing I told you. Okay? Do you remember what I told you?

Speaker: mae mobley
Dialogue: To wipe my bottom good?

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: No, Baby. The other. What you are.

Speaker: mae mobley
Dialogue: You is kind. You is smart. You is important.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: That's right, Baby Girl. Aibileen squeezes Mae Mobley for the last time. They both cry together. Hilly speaks up.

Speaker: hilly
Dialogue: You need to go now, Aibileen! Aibileen rises up from Mae Mobley and turns to Elizabeth.

Speaker: aibileen
Dialogue: Give my sweet girl a chance. Elizabeth avoids eye contact. Aibileen turns and walks away. As Elizabeth leans down to pick up Mae Mobley....HER WATER BREAKS. She glares at Hilly with shock and regret.

Speaker: mae mobley
Dialogue: Aibeeeee! Don't go! Aibileen never turns.

Speaker: constantine jefferson
Dialogue: Born December 24th 1883 Died March 15th, 1963 A bouquet of flowers lay at the foot of the tombstone. A copy of "The Help" leans against it. In the distance, a cab slowly pulls away with Skeeter inside.
